conclusion: The lamp is being moved until it is practically 'on top' of the scene, causing rays that reach the objects to be close to vertical.
In this situation, every point of every object projects straight downward, so each shadow finishes up directly underneath its object and becomes as short as it can possibly be.
Shadow length is proportional to tan θ, and θ approaches 90° as the lamp moves overhead.
What happens to each numbered shadow is identical in principle: shadows move directly below their objects and shrink in size.
Present image: Shadow A (shadow of the egg) is a long horizontal ellipse lying to the left of the egg.
After the lamp is overhead, Shadow A migrates to the floor spot exactly below the egg and contracts to a small, almost circular patch whose diameter is about the same as the egg’s equator.
Present image: Shadow B (shadow of the alarm-clock body) is a stretched, pill-shaped patch lying left of the clock.
After the lamp is overhead, Shadow B slides inwards until it sits under the clock; its outline becomes a near-perfect circle only a little smaller than the clock face itself.
Present image: Shadow C (shadow of the clock’s feet/knobs) is a separate dark blot a little farther left and downward from the main body shadow.
After the lamp is overhead, Shadow C contracts and merges with Shadow B, becoming a tiny pair of spots immediately beside the circular body shadow.
Present image: Shadow D (shadow of the small ornamental branch) is an irregular, expanded outline off to the left of the branch.
After the lamp is overhead, Shadow D shifts to the ground directly below the branch and shrinks to an outline that is only as large as the branch’s horizontal 'footprint'.
Overall result: Every shadow moves toward – and ends up centred under – its parent object.
Overall result: Each shadow’s length collapses, leaving only a compact 'footprint' roughly matching the object’s top-view shape.
